awd_titl_txt: EPCN:Solving Electricity-Expansion Problems Efficiently via Decomposition (SEEPED)
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to transform the manner in which electric power system capacity-expansion problems are modeled. Capacity-expansion problems are large-scale and complex, due to the nature of power systems (spanning continents and including thousands of nodes and branches) and the numerous uncertainties plaguing long-term planning decisions. This includes large-scale uncertainties, such as long-term demand growth, changes in fuel prices, energy-policy choices, and technology development; and small-scale uncertainties, such as weather events affecting real-time demand and wind and solar availability. This project will develop modeling paradigms that capture the multiple scales of planning decisions and the uncertainties that affect them within a coherent framework. This is a timely and fundamentally important endeavor to ensure an efficient transition to more sustainable and resilient power system designs. 

We will tackle this challenging problem by developing two complementary approaches to modeling power system capacity expansion. Both approaches model multi-scale uncertainties and decisions and represent system operations in sufficient detail to capture system flexibility needs. The first approach uses a multi-stage stochastic optimization approach, in which investment decisions are made at coarse (e.g., decadal) timescales and operating decisions are made at fine (e.g., hourly) timescales, with full representation of the temporal sequence of these decisions. Large-scale uncertainties are modeled explicitly in the scenario tree, while small-scale uncertainties are captured through different operating conditions. The other approach is an adaptive robust stochastic model, in which planning decisions are made to be robust or distributionally robust to large-scale uncertainties and take stochastic operating conditions into account. These complex and large-scale models are accompanied by decomposition algorithms. The progressive hedging algorithm will be adapted to tractably solve the multi-stage stochastic optimization model while column-and-constraint algorithms will be developed for solving the robust model. We will also explore the use of clustering and importance sampling techniques to select representative operating periods to be modeled between investment epochs. The use, tractability, and power of the proposed modeling techniques will be demonstrated using large-scale case studies based on North American power systems. The PIs will also engage with electricity industry members. They will also use industry- and government-advisory positions to advance industry dissemination. These steps will ensure that the results of the research are used by industry members while at the same time industry can provide vital feedback and input to model and case study development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new methods for modeling and optimizing capacity-planning decisions for electricity systems. To this end, the project developed modeling paradigms that capture the multiple scales of planning decisions and the uncertainties that affect them within a coherent framework. In addition, this project developed modeling approaches to understand the role of different technologies (e.g., energy storage, flexible electricity-demand response, and varying natural-gas supplies) in easing or complicating electricity-system operations and planning with high penetration of renewable energy, decarbonization constraints, or other factors that complicate such exercises. The project focused also on how policy or market-design decisions can ease of complicate electricity-system operations and planning and the impacts of different technologies thereupon. Finally, the project developed decomposition and relaxation algorithm that allow for solving large-scale planning problems efficiently.

These goals were achieved along the following primary research thrusts.

  1. Studying how capacity need of electricity systems evolve with high penetrations of renewable energy and the role of hybrid resources that consist of renewable energy and energy storage to fulfill those needs.
  2. Developing tractable models and decomposition algorithms to plan electricity systems with high penetrations of renewable energy and seasonal or interannual energy storage in the form of reservoir hydroelectric generation.
  3. Understanding how the designs of wholesale electricity markets and price formation therein evolve as the penetration of renewable energy increases. This research thrust studied also decarbonization-policy choices interact with decision making by profit-motivated agents in wholesale electricity markets and can yield inefficiencies.
  4. Understanding how vertical integration in energy markets (e.g., natural-gas suppliers that merge with electricity-generation firms) can impact market design and the exercise of market power. Interactions between electricity and natural-gas markets and systems is of vital importance, because electricity systems are becoming more dependent upon natural-gas-fired generation to provide necessary supply-side flexibility.
  5. Understanding how wholesale markets may need to change to engender the level of supply- and demand-side operational flexibility that is needed to balance electricity supply and demand. This need for operational flexibility will be exacerbated by the increasing penetrations of renewable energy in electricity systems.
  6. Understanding the ability to exploit flexibility in the demands of water-treatment, -distribution, and -desalination systems as a form of demand-side flexibility and demand response in electricity systems. This work supplements the fifth research thrust.
  7. Developing models that can ascertain the contribution of limited-energy resources (e.g., energy storage or demand response) to electricity-system reliability and resource adequacy. Given the transition away from the use of fossil fuels for electricity production, there is a need to understand the capability of carbon-free energy resources to maintain reliable electricity supply.
